reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central methodological move: evaluating how likely mostly-great futures are under a baseline conditional on survival and “no serious de dicto optimization,” and using that to support the claim that the target is narrow by default. If that baseline is incoherent or systematically mischaracterized, the paper’s probability claims about default trajectories are weakened, though many other parts (e.g., the normative ‘fussiness’ analysis of value functions, and the multiplicative-fragility intuition) can survive with a different baseline—so centrality is substantial but not total.

Strength is moderate. The critique plausibly argues that many highlighted “failure modes” are indeed decision points that arise endogenously with capability (digital minds, space expansion, governance), so a world with no explicit de dicto optimization still involves institutional selection and implicit optimization. That undercuts any interpretation of the baseline as ‘neutral, no-aiming, no-steering.’ However, the paper can reply that it meant “no deliberate aiming at the best de dicto” rather than “no optimization whatsoever,” and that the baseline is precisely meant to include unreflective/path-dependent/power-driven choices; the critique doesn’t show that such a baseline can’t be modeled, only that it needs explicit institutional/political assumptions. Also, even if the baseline is reframed as ‘unreflective default governance,’ the paper’s core claim (that mostly-great futures are unlikely absent targeted steering) may still hold.

Correctness is fairly high: it’s largely true that capability forces choices and that defaults are a kind of selection. The main potential overreach is the claim of outright “incoherence,” since the baseline can be coherent if defined as “no coordinated de dicto best-outcome optimization” rather than “no selection among institutions.”

Clarity is high: the objection is easy to state and track, and it proposes a concrete fix (model default institutional selection).

Dead weight is low; nearly all sentences contribute.

Single-issue focus is strong: it concentrates on the baseline/counterfactual and its implications.

Overall, it’s a meaningful methodological pressure on the paper’s empirical/probabilistic framing, but not a decisive refutation of the broader ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion.
title: Capability growth forces optimization so the no-aiming baseline is incoherent
